comment: It pains me that when hard work is expected of students at Ksu, they claim it is incompetence of the professor. The class was structured around readings and thinking critically about them. Those who cut corners got penalized. No mediocrity here. Dr. Govens was caring and willing to help in any way possible (even beyond the course material). 10/10.

He's a great guy but really expects you to put a lot of time and effort into his assignments. He's got a lot of degrees and has been to some prestigious schools so make sure you're willing to put all the effort he expects. We wrote 2 big papers and had weekly reading responses. He said he'd make us do quizzes and tests if we didn't put in effort.

Although he only gives one assignment per week, Dr. Govens expects that assignment to be the greatest work ever written. His lectures can be inspiring, however the grading criteria can vary greatly! He would take off points for the smallest thing and would not really explain how to improve. I worked hard but only received mediocre feedback.

Grading expectations are seemingly arbitrary and vary wildly from assignment to assignment. Hes also really condescending and was late to class several times. Not appreciative of differences in opinion. If you get stuck with him, just suck up and overdo every single assignment.

He cares for the students, that's for sure. Dr. Govens is passionate about the subjects and ties the work into real life. He has LOTS of stories, which can be long, but they always relate to the topic you're studying. He's funny too. I'd take his class again.

Never wanted to talk about the major assignments in class and told us to ask the "peer mentor," who turned around and asked him. Takes big chunks of points off for small things, sometimes directly contradicts the rubric in class while saying the rubric was perfectly clear. This class was pass/fail and it caused more stress than anatomy for me.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Govens is a great professor. Class participation is a must so be prepared for that. He really does care about his students and it shows. One thing I will note is that he can get carried away with personal stories that are a little boring.

In the essays given, make sure you make it personal and give examples and that makes a big difference in his grading. For the written daily reviews make sure you read the rubric because he follows it exactly. If you miss a page he takes off a lot of points so make sure you keep up with them. For the reading prompts just give examples within the ?'s
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things
